Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: FRED BAINES
Present address: 814 STOCKWELL AVENUE, NELOWNA, BC.
Pioneer address: CRESCENT LAKE
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1883

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1921, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? About ten.

How many of these were bachelor's homes? Practically none.

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Several times during the year.

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Usually on Sundays to religious services, meeting many friends thereat.

4. Were you often invited to other homes? Or was most visiting done without an invitation? Welcomed at all times.

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Owing to distance, often most of the day.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Meals always served - distance made it necessary.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Yes - stay to dinner. Eat as we eat.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? We always stayed for meals - always made welcome.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Generally the whole family.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Bees often held for the building - never heard of fulfilling debts in those days - no materials! Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. We all enjoyed a general get-together, usually winding up with a party and dancing fiddle, mouth organ, & banjo.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe. Not many - transportation too tedious, mostly oxen.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates. Yes, as transportation speeded up - ponies - later cars.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No - only casually.
PIONEER BARRACKS AND SOCIAL LIFE.

1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth about ten times?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Occasionally or rarely?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays or other days? Generally or occasionally?

4. Were you often invited to other homes? Yes - always served - distance made it necessary.

5. What time of the day did you go? - in the morning and evening, the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

6. How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had some unexpected company? (That is, was the term used to "make polite" used, or was some other expression common?)

7. If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in unexpectedly?

8. Did you ever have "dinner parties"? Did anyone ever come together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such projects?

9. Did you ever have "family reunions"? Did anyone ever gather at lakes if possible, tall-

10. We all enjoyed a general get-together, usually winding up with a party and dancing.

11. Not many - transportation too tedious mostly over.

12. Have there been frequent in later years? Give dates.

13. Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn, once a month, etc.?
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire.) Give dates.

Picnics usually held at Lake side. Christmas trees, concerts, box socials and dances invariably held at school houses.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

The greater part of it, political meetings, etc.

9. When was your first community hall built? When, the first school house was built. What material was it made of? Lumber. How large was it? 18 x 24 ft.

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.? Wm Eakin. By deputations.

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

School built in center of school district.

To what extent did you take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?)

Gatherings held both in school and town, as cars came in general use.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

Not always.

How were babies and small children provided for?

In corners by elderly ladies.

How were houses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties?

At sheds provided.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Poker, Euchre and several other types of card games.

Was there card playing for a prize? They used to gamble frequently.

What dances were popular? Waltzes, Square dances, Folks, Shottisches, Highland Fling, Red River jig, Step dancing.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. Yes, revival meetings preached against dancing.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Card playing and dancing were frequently tabooed.
2. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, etc., and other entertainments held at the school. Christmas tree, plantation, etc.

Pianos usually held at school parties. Christmas parties, box socials and dances invariably held at school houses.

The greater part of it. Political meetings, etc.

9. How was your school community hall built? When, by whom, by what method?

Was built in the village of town. It was a community hall. It was built by the town. It was built by the school board. It was built by the community through special funds. The municipality, some organization, etc.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in questions 9, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend?

Yes, always. No, only children attended. Sometimes, yes; sometimes, no.

11. What card games were popular in the early days?

Poker, Euchre, and several other types of card games. What dances were popular? Waltzes, square dances, jigs, schottisches, highland spring, quadrille, etc.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain. Card playing and dancing were frequently refused.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

Very little ceremony attended early gatherings.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Yes, occasionally.

Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

They often got out of hand and damage was caused.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc. that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

Horse-throwing was popular. Bronco Busting and athletic jumping contests.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

The Farmers' Union, later the Grain Growers, later the Co-operative Association.

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

From 1902 to 1912 or 1914. To break monopoly and oppression by the grain magnates who gouged the (agriculturalists)

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

The above answers this query.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

Practically all of them.

How many women belonged? Various. How often did it meet? Whenever necessary.

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

Social gatherings, questionnaires, explanations, subscriptions for delegates to conventions, etc.

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No

When was it organized? X

Approximately how many women belonged to it? X

Describe what you remember of its activities and services. X
12. What attempts at formality or "nawaka" do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visiting cards used ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

Very little ceremony attended early gatherings.

13. Was the shivaree known in your community? Yes, occasionally.

Describe what you remember about shivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

They often got out of hand and damaged property.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember.

In visiting or social life, boomerang was used. You could throw it and then catch it.

Boomerang was popular. Brooches, buttons, and necklaces were popular.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community?

The Homemakers' Club was organized in 1916 by Mrs. Smith.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Club in your community?

Yes, there was a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Club in your community.

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

Here was a strong organization.

Social gatherings, fund-raising, educational meetings, etc.

Yes, there was a Homemakers' Club in your district.

When was it organized?

22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 
In our district of Crescent Lake, owing to its scattered population and difficult means of transportation very little 
sport was played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? Cards, Authors, 
checkers, dominoes, music and dancing.

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.
Yes - Everyone.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind 
of work? Explain.
The problem of keeping the homes supplied with fuel consumed a great deal of their spare time. 
Wood was rarely used.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrow 
heads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.
Frank Baines was the local collector of natural curiosities and his collection of such was and is 
of considerable interest. The only one worthwhile record, N.S. Some extensive egg collections received 
special mention from the zoological societies.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?
Give year and month if possible. Swanport, 1884, at present 
Lake.

26. Who organized it?
Mr. W.M. Earle (later Speaker of Legislative Assembly) of Sask.

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school 
district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.?
Just settlers - no schools active.

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? Yes.
If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, 
etc.)?
Just a get-together - lunch etc., and water 
police.

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did 
families and friends form smaller groups?
All together (a free for all).

31. What did you have to eat and drink?
Roast wild fowl, Saskatoon, gooseberries wild 
cherries / black currants. Tea, only - no coffee in 
those days, no spirituous liquids.

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
All afternoon until the mosquitoes took charge.
II. Describe any features of this picnic which you consider outstanding.

The atmosphere of good will, the hope for the future, plans discussed for church and social services.

III. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you know of in the early days, such as the large community picnics, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell also any differences in matters attending, activities, games, etc., held, etc.

Some subsequent picnics included in athletic sports, horse racing, winding up with the inevitable dance, some liquor appearing.

IV. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first picnic? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

From the nineties on, picnics became events of large attendance. Baseball, horse racing, midways and merry-go-rounds, featured extensively.

V. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Answered above.

VI. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Baseball.

What year? From the records, how long did it continue? Until the present day.

VII. Were any other sports teams that were organized before 1912, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger meetings, etc.

Yes, hockey creates universal competition, curling gets equal recognition.

VIII. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, skating, etc.).

Around 1902 for hockey and skating.

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?

Answered above.
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? 1889

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic? To a certain extent it did.

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? The leading citizens; many new dead and gone.

When was the sports day usually held? (What month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names and dates.

No very outstanding individuals, some local celebrities.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

A few English schoolbooks until Elementary text books became obligatory.

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? Not many.

What kind of books and how many? Largely Bibles, hymn books, a few historical classics.

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Considerably.

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

No, not many—cash very scarce.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years? Subscriptions to periodicals and weekly newspapers.

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

Yes, several attempts, dating from 1888.

48. Was there a school library? No.

When was it begun? No.

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

Very little, if any.

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts as additional reading material?

Yes, surely.

MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you?
Our own vocal musical accomplishments (ie singing)

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? We used violins,
guitars, banjos, concertinas and harmonicas.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give
dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
Banjo - $2.00
1900 Banjo - $2.00 Piano - 1921 - $40.00
1903 Organ - $18.00

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainments in early years in the West? Describe.
The principal most entertaining part.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.
Yes - musical concerts, individual and community singing of great interests.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home? The old Ontario Songs - negro melodies, sacred songs and Western songs. Cowboy Laments - House on the Range.

Yes - some local composers did so, with telling effect.

63. Was there a band in your community? Yes. When was it started? 1889.
Who started it? New name dead and gone, names forgotten.
How long did it continue? A member of years.
How many were in it? About 15 Who was bandmaster? In later years S. Bruner.
What instruments were included? A full set of band instruments purchased by the town of Salt Lake.
Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
Practice held twice weekly, usually in town hall. Uniforms - played at all leading events, holidays and political gatherings.

Practice held three times weekly, usually at town hall, uniformed at all occasions, event, holiday and political gathering.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

Yes. Frank Baines of Saltcoats has become a musician of high standing and favorably known as an artist of exceptional ability.

Saltcoats, Sask., has also become notable as a center of vocal and composition studies—K.L. Baines, head of Saltcoats' music school, has won distinction by winning the first prize in the international competition for the composition of a new folk song.

To those it may concern,

Fred Baines, late of Saltcoats, Sask., now of the above address,
kindly forward the latest statistical statement forwarded from
Saltcoats to me at Kelowna, B.C. These records have caused much
searching of reminiscences, and are such as I can reasonably
provide, and I apologize accordingly.

I am now permanently located in B.C., having lived in
Saskatchewan since the year 1863. August of that year,
as an immigrant from Manchester, England. I have lived
nearly 70 years in Canadian West, 64 of them in the province
of Assiniboia, later Saskatchewan, and have noted the many
progressions to the present civilizations.

My memory of earlier years is still fresh on my mind,
and I can see the future of the Canadian West looming
up as a brilliant future of great things to come.

If more is required of me, address all communications to
the above address, and I have left Saltcoats for good.

Yours truly — Fred S. Baines
814 Stockwell Avenue
Kelowna, B.C.
To those of my Concern,

Fred Baines, late of Saltcoats, Sask., now of the above address,

really forward the latest statistical statement forwarded from Saltcoats & Co. at Kelowna, B.C. These records have caused much searching of reminiscence, and not such as I can reasonably

believe, and I apologize accordingly. In B.C., having lived in

Saskatchewan since the year 1868, August of that year.

As an immigrant from Manchester, England, I have lived

really 70 years in Canadian West by far oftentimes in the province

of Assiniboia, later Saskatchewan, and have noted the many

progressions & the present civilizations.

My memory of earlier years is still fresh on my mind,

and I can see the future of the Canadian West looming

up as a brilliant future of great things to come.

If more is required of me, add me all communications.

The above address, as I have left Saltcoats for good.

Yours Truly — Fred A. Baines

614 Stockwell Avenue
Kelowna, B.C.
